fields.description:
Currently, we run Valgrind on a coverage-enabled C++ build on Travis-CI. This means the slowness of Valgrind acts as a multiplier of the overhead of outputting coverage information using the instrumentation added by the compiler.

Instead we should probably emit C++ (and Python) coverage information in a different Travis-CI build without Valgrind enabled.
fields.summary: [CI] Run Valgrind and C++ code coverage in different bulds

comments.body: I would prefer to do ARROW-3803 if we can first (consolidate C++ tests in their own build, and Python tests in their own build)
Considering how slow the tests under Valgrind are in Travis CI we might consider running only ASAN in Travis CI and instead running Valgrind in a nightly build
I'm not up-to-date on ASAN. Does it require a recent clang for useful results?

I agree that valgrind does provide useful insights. It can find things (like memory leaks) that that ASAN does not. It requires an up to date clang indeed

Lucky because the way we manage memory, leaks in the C++ are rare which has been nice
ASAN also does [memory leak|https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/AddressSanitizerLeakSanitizer] detection, albeit not as good as valgrind.

This change would decrease the runtime of the longest job from 35 to 29 minutes, but would increase agregate CPU consumption (since there would be one more build):

[https://travis-ci.org/pitrou/arrow/builds/474879617]

Thoughts?
I think this is OK for now -- we should look more seriously at moving valgrind runs to dedicated hardware (ie Jenkins) where we can request builds using a bot.
